statement.tex: \text{Find the second order derivative of the }\\ \text{function }\log (\log x).

step.context: \text{What do you understand by the second}\\ \text{order derivative of a function f(x)?}
\text{Is the following the correct way to }\\ \text{find } \dfrac{d^2(f(x))}{dx^2}?\text{where f(x) = \log (\log x).}
step.tex:
\begin{align} \dfrac{d(f(x))}{dx} &= \dfrac{d(\log (\log x))}{dx}\\ &= \dfrac{1}{\log x}.\dfrac{d(\log x)}{dx}\\ &=\dfrac{1}{x .\log x}\\ \end{align}\\
\begin{align} \dfrac{d^2(f(x))}{dx^2} &= \dfrac{d\Bigg(\dfrac{1}{x .\log x}\Bigg)}{dx}\\ &= \underbrace{\dfrac{\dfrac{d(1)}{dx}.d(x . \log x) +\dfrac{d(x . \log x)}{dx}}{(x . \log x)^2}}_{Quotient Rule}\\ &=-\dfrac{(1+\log x)}{(x \log x)^2}\\ \end{align}\\
step.reason: \text{Other than Quotient Rule we have used the fact}\\ \text{that }\dfrac{d(\log x)}{dx} = \dfrac{1}{x}.\text{Check your calculation if you}\\ \text{got something else}.
